entry.title: Combined summary - multisig, op_eval and lock_time/sequence...
entry.summary: Michael Grønager proposed a solution for multisig transactions, where a transaction is issued with one signature and posted to the p2p network. Client2 discovers the transaction and modifies it to include the second signature, which makes it valid and final, approved by miners. However, they need to re-enable the replacement of transactions in the client for this setup to work. Alternatively, transactions could be sent between clients using another protocol. BIP 0010 was created to encourage a standard that developers can adopt from the outset. It solves the problem of multi-sig tx exchanges, which every developer planning to touch multi-signature transactions will eventually face.The email conversation between Michael Gronager and Mike Hearn is about introducing other protocols, specifically regarding escrow transactions in BitCoinJ. While Gronager expresses concern about the introduction of other protocols because they might never become standard, Hearn argues that BIPs should not be a place for people to come up with armchair designs without actual implementation. He believes that partially-signed transactions should not belong on the main Bitcoin P2P network due to the possibility of spamming bogus data, but suggests a half-baked idea of using the blockchain to distribute signatures by broadcasting complete transactions that contain extra signatures for the transaction that needs to be signed. The parties would have to pay for the extra data they include, but it would allow for immediate worldwide distribution of half-baked transactions.In this context, Gavin Andresen discusses the use of block-chain for transactions and the possibility of adding arbitrary stuff in scriptSig. He also talks about the potential issue of gunking up the block chain with more data and how parties involved in the transaction would have to pay for the extra data they are including. There is also a discussion about whether it would be cheaper/better to not use the block chain to distribute signatures and the possibility of creating a separate P2P network for off-band information like this. The possibility of using another protocol to gather signatures is also mentioned.The purpose of creating BIP 0010 is to encourage a standard for multi-signature transactions that developers want to adopt from the outset. The txout scripts are critical to adoption, and including them in the txin scripts for signing is very important. By offering this solution before developers start asking the question of how to do it is exactly what's needed. In the same way, every developer who is planning to touch multi-signature transactions is going to have to solve the problem of multi-sig tx exchanges eventually. Formats and protocols for gathering signatures are in the TODO category.Michael Gronager shared his thoughts on the creation of Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs) without actual implementation. He emphasized that BIPs should not be a place for people to come up with designs without corresponding implementation, as it is likely to be full of problems. Gronager proposed an escrow protocol that requires the seller to challenge the dispute mediator using the existing DNS/EV-SSL infrastructure. He also mentioned that BIPs should revisit these proposals once software can be installed and tested on laptops, servers, and friends' servers. In another thread, Michael proposed a multisig transaction format for clients and received feedback on its format and design.A developer named Alan Reiner proposed BIP 0010 to encourage a standard that developers want to adopt, from the outset. The purpose of BIP 0010 is to offer an excellent solution before developers start asking questions about multi-sig tx exchanges. Protocols get fragmented when there are multiple competing ways to do something, each having some advantages the others don't have. If anyone has ideas for why someone would want to create a competing idea to BIP 0010 (besides not being aware of it when they start), he would like to discuss it.The context of the discussion is about the multisig/op_eval BIPs (11/12) and how the client functionality could be. The proposal suggests that in a 2 of 3 multisig scenario, when a user wants to spend their coins they would issue a transaction containing one of the signatures from their client1 with a lock time of 10 minutes from now and a sequence of 0, then client2 would discover the transaction, modify it to include the second signature, change the sequence to 0xFFFFFFFF=final, and retransmit the transaction. The transaction is now valid and final and will be approved by the miners.The discussion is regarding the use of Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIP) and the importance of having a working end-to-end implementation before proposing standards track BIPs. Mike Hearn suggests that design discussions should be held on the mailing list, while BIPs should be reserved for proposals with actual implementations behind them. He also emphasizes the need for credible standards track BIPs to avoid technical decisions taken months earlier, which could lead to bizarre user experiences. Alan agrees with the need for collaboration to come up with a good solution
